awd_titl_txt: An Engineer Like Me: How Perceived Similarity and Peer Effects Influence Student Major Choice
awd_abstract_narration:
This Improving Undergraduate STEM Education (IUSE) project will investigate the factors that influence the under-representation of female and minority students in engineering. Data from the College of Engineering at Purdue University will be used for the analyses, which provides an opportunity to examine a large population of engineering students. The project has the following objectives: (1) to investigate how students' peers and role models, both from the student and faculty populations within each major, can affect students choice of major, (2) to investigate how the messaging and information students receive in the course of choosing their major can affect which field they will enter, and (3) to establish how and why major choices change over time. The analysis will combine methods from economics and education to provide comprehensive mixed-methods analysis of how classroom environments and activities can influence student major choice. The proposed research is aimed at explaining why substantial variations in diversity exist across engineering disciplines as a function of student classroom experiences the demographic composition of students peers and faculty, but also the messages that students receive regarding the values and career prospects of the different disciplines through classroom activities and interventions. The successful completion of the project will significantly complement ongoing efforts to increase recruitment efforts across engineering disciplines.

The importance and the role of engineering education in today's economic environment have been receiving growing attention. With the nation's call for a larger and more diverse engineering labor force, it is timely and critical to better understand how multiple factors including classroom environments and peers, messaging from discipline representatives, and departmental-level demographic composition intersect to influence students' academic and career trajectories. This project has the potential to advance knowledge in several fields, notably economics and engineering education. An important contribution of this project will be the additional focus on messaging and information available to students. This research project's interpretive inquiry approach using both inductive and deductive strategies is based on a broad range of interview participants. Findings will generate new insights that have important implications for the development of strategies to recruit more women and underrepresented minorities into the different engineering disciplines.  If messaging is shown to be an important avenue by which institutions can affect major choice, this type of intervention will be very scalable and could have significant impacts on the representation of female and minority students within other STEM fields. The project includes efforts to communicate the results of this work to the broader engineering education community.

por.por_cntn:
Increasing the number and diversity of students who major and graduate in engineering is critical to the U.S. workforce, economic development, and technological innovations. To help inform strategies and program development useful for recruiting and retaining engineering students, particularly women and racially minoritized students, we conducted a mixed-methods research study on a selective public research university in the Midwest with a large engineering program. We analyzed transcript data combined with interviews with 39 first-year engineering students to investigate which factors and experiences during the first-year of an engineering program influences engineering major choice, academic performance, and persistence. We identified several factors that contribute to students? engineering major decision-making and likelihood of graduation in engineering. We also developed a conceptual model illustrating the key factors across students? life stages (pre-high school, high school, and first year of college) that are associated with engineering major choice. 

Intellectual Merit:

Our study isolated a number of experiences during the first year that are important to predicting the success and persistence of women and racially minoritized students in engineering.  Our results identified the ways in which the students? environment in the first- year engineering program, including the courses that they take, the advising information that they receive, and the demographic composition of their peers and faculty, can impact perceptions of engineering and subsequent academic outcomes.  

In terms of peer effects, Black/African American and Hispanic/Latinx students are more likely to earn higher grades in their class when they have more peers from their same racial/ethnic group in their class.  Similarly, a higher proportion of female students in the classroom has a positive influence on all students in the course, making them more likely to stay within the engineering school after the first year.  It is not only peer demographics that can influence engineering student academic success.  Engineering students in classes with greater proportions of peers with higher academic achievement are more successful in those classes. Instructor characteristics are also important. We find that female students benefit from having a female teaching assistant in their first engineering course.  Female students earn higher grades and are more likely to pick a more competitive and higher paying field of engineering if they are taught by a female teaching assistant. 

Broader Impacts:

Our research project resulted in 3 published peer-reviewed articles, 1 manuscript under review, and 4 working papers to be submitted for review.  We also presented 12 papers at national conferences in economics, higher education, engineering education, and education finance and policy. We have also been invited to present our findings at seminars across six different institutions, and have shared our work with relevant stakeholders across multiple engineering programs. Altogether, this project has helped support the research trajectories of 5 undergraduate students and 3 PhD students.

Our research has identified several factors and experiences that can help increase participation and diversity, as well as student academic achievement, in engineering. Stakeholders, faculty, administrators, and policy makers can use this information toward enhancing programs and interventions to encourage students to pursue engineering and to consider the wide range of engineering majors available. This will in turn help to build a stronger workforce in the United States. Our research findings also highlight factors that are associated with students? increased graduation probabilities, and thus can be useful to engineering programs and student services office to aid in their efforts to support students as they pursue their degrees. Our work has contributed to the literature on diversity in engineering, as well as to the literature in economics on peer and instructor effects, and has been disseminated to a wide range of audiences across multiple fields.
